text: this is Suzy Menkes in Paris for the New
York Times and the International Herald
Tribune and I with Kim Jones the men's
style director celui Bhutan Jim Jones is
taking over this season at Louis Vuitton
doing the menswear that he's done for
ten years since he left some Martin's
College of Art in London here at Louie
wheat on he's found his spiritual home
because this is a man as well as a brand
that loves travel brought up in Africa
King Jones has a real feeling for the
texture for the colors and what better
person to be carrying the Louis Vuitton
bags and wearing the clothes and the
shoes than the man who has himself
designed them
louboutin is all about travel that's the
soul of the brand but for you the soul
of your design is really your experience
growing up in Africa yes I mean I think
you know I was always very aware of
think around me and I always was
obsessed by animals we'd be staying out
in the middle of the bush because my
dad's job was to go and find wells for
people and there would be you know you'd
see like a herd of elephants walking
across a pan in Botswana or you know
stones I still have stones and things I
had when I was four years old that I
have on my mantelpiece a time and you
know those colors and those things all
influenced you who you are these wood
carvings of the famous Louboutin symbols
in a way they get to the heart of your
collection would that be right I think
the collection is very much greatest
from the Maasai and looking at East
Africa I was looking for something that
embodied that sort of old worldliness of
that but with the symbols of this new
world and um these were perfect and
these all actually made out of bits of
boats so it's completely reclaimed I
think ISM made that's not on purpose and
I think that's what makes them so
beautiful and I think it's kind of a
good way to work new versions of the
Damier or the monogram and have fun with
those elements of the burn
only the shoes we haven't looked at now
yes and here we've gone from taking the
idea of going from being in town and
going out for adventure then evening but
evening in the bush not actually in town
so this is a sandal oh wow that's real
travel is your total travel look where
it folds completely flat and so you can
sit them in the bottom of your suitcase
and you can take them to the beach I'm
quite intrigued by these pieces of our
called transforming pieces those bags
when you can fold it down or do various
things with it is it do you have this
idea really that you transform things I
was just looking at things that make it
as easy as possible for uncomfortable
for the customer to travel with it this
kind of the idea of me just panicking in
the airport that you have got enough
room in your bag and you bought too many
things I just think it's very practical
and I think that's how I think I'm kind
of a logical practical thinker at the
